Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Production and Political Use of Social Science during Extended Periods of Cold War Unrest and Instability

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Project Overview

This historical study examines how the psychological sciences in Argentina became a crucial weapon in the ideological battle for loyalty during the Cold War in the global South, which is characterized by political instability, ideological polarization, and bloodshed. The proposed study includes both archival research and interviews with key historical actors in Argentina. There are two core questions that will be investigated: How did political actors use the psychological sciences to advance ideological goals during the height of Cold War political extremism in Argentina, from 1966 to 1983? How did psychologists and psychiatrists embed political values into psychological theory and practice during this period?

Intellectual Merit

This study focuses on the interaction between social-scientific knowledge production and the volatile politics that characterized the Cold War below the equator. The vast majority of Cold War studies of social science focus on social science under the peace and stability of the US and Soviet superpowers. By contrast, this study contribute to the growing body of literature that examines how ideological polarization, grassroots activism, and political violence in the global south affected the production and political use of social science during the Cold War. Argentina provides a useful case for study because of its rich tradition in the psychological sciences.

Broader Impacts

The Co-PI plans to present his research findings to psychologists at seminars and conferences in Buenos Aires and to publish in a Spanish-language psychology journal, in addition to presenting them at psychology conferences and publishing them in psychology journals in the US. The Co-PI also plans to donate his collected oral histories of psychologists who were politically active during the Cold War to the Memoria Abierta Oral Archive in Argentina. Doing so will not only shed light on a period for which documentation is sparse due to political repression, but also to advance the human rights organization's goals of preserving memory of state violence, enriching democratic culture, and preventing the return of authoritarianism in Argentina.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Marco Antonio Ramos has completed research for his dissertation “Production and Political Use of Social Science during Extended Periods of Cold War Unrest and Instability.” His project concerns the political use of psychiatry, psychology, and psychoanalysis during the 1970s and early 1980s in Argentina. During this period, Argentine society was torn between both the violence of revolutionary guerrilla groups and a series of authoritarian anti-Communist dictatorships backed by weapons and training from the United States. From 1976 to 1983, anti-Communist violence and rhetoric reached a fever pitch under the leadership of General Jorge Rafael Videla. He launched la Guerra Sucia [the Dirty War], a term that conveyed the “dirty” tactics, including political disappearance and torture, deemed necessary to fight Communist “subversion” in Argentina. Ramos’ dissertation will investigate how the psychological sciences provided a crucial instrument in the ideological battle for Argentine hearts and minds amid this violence and political extremism.

            During his funding period, Ramos conducted archival research and interviews with key historical actors for over a year in Argentina. Much of his research took place in military archives in Buenos Aires, which contained documentation on how the military used psychiatry and psychology in their dirty war against Communist "subversion." Ramos also conducted interviews with, among others, members of the Equipo de Asistencia Psicológica, a group of activist psychologists and psychiatrists who advocated for human rights and the return of democracy. Ramos is in the process of donating these oral histories to the Memoria Abierta Archive in Argentina. These donations will not only shed light on a period for which documentation is sparse? due to political repression, but also advance the human rights organization’s goals of preserving memory of state violence, enriching democratic culture, and preventing the return ?of authoritarianism in Argentina.

            In the course of his research, Ramos discovered that psychiatry and psychology were used as tools for both oppression and political resistance. A large number of psychiatrists engaged in activism against authoritarian oppression, while others supported and participated in the regime’s machinations. Mental asylums, for example, served as clandestine centers of detention where one psychiatrist and former director of the Instituto Nacional de Salud Mental [National Institute of Mental Health] oversaw a program that institutionalized and possibly tortured those deemed subversive to the established order. In contrast, psychiatrists associated with the openly Marxist Federación Argentina de Psiquiatras [Argentine Federation of Psychiatrists], the largest professional psychiatric organization in Argentina at the time, resisted the military by organizing strikes, proposing progressive legislation, and criticizing mental health law that in their view neglected the state’s duty to provide mental health care to all its citizens. For both historical and ethical reasons, it is important to ask not only how psychiatry and psychology, disciplines centered on bettering the lives of patients, aided in the oppression of Argentine citizens, but also how the psychological sciences provided a platform for resistance against an authoritarian state.
